body_html:
The linux-xenial-cuda8-cudnn6-py3 and linux-xenial-cuda9-cudnn7-py2 failures are both caused when trying to trigger the assertion using REQUIRE_THROWS(ti.collapseDims(5)).

I am not totally sure why this is happening. Would you recommend removing this test? The assertion replaces several assertions in the original and is comparable to another assert in reduceDim(), so that seems appropriate to keep.

EDIT: Nevermind. This was just an error in the commit. Fixing now.

EDIT EDIT: Fixed by removing the test. The PyTorch standard seems to be to assert() in this case (from assert.h). Catch2 does not support catching aborts currently, see catchorg/Catch2#853. This suggests removing the test is the correct fix.

EDIT: Nevermind. This was just an error in the commit. Fixing now.
EDIT EDIT: Fixed by removing the test. The PyTorch standard seems to be to assert() in this case (from assert.h). Catch2 does not support catching aborts currently, see catchorg/Catch2#853. This suggests removing the test is the correct fix.
body:
The linux-xenial-cuda8-cudnn6-py3 and linux-xenial-cuda9-cudnn7-py2 failures are both caused when trying to trigger the assertion using REQUIRE_THROWS(ti.collapseDims(5)). 

I am not totally sure why this is happening. Would you recommend removing this test? The assertion replaces several assertions in the original and is comparable to another assert in reduceDim(), so that seems appropriate to keep.

EDIT: Nevermind. This was just an error in the commit. Fixing now.

EDIT EDIT: Fixed by removing the test. The PyTorch standard seems to be to assert() in this case (from assert.h). Catch2 does not support catching aborts currently, see https://github.com/catchorg/Catch2/issues/853. This suggests removing the test is the correct fix.
